abstract.p: Prof Sanders Korenman letter disputes August 11 article on decline in child poverty rate in booming US economy

block.p: Re your Aug. 11 news article reporting that the national child poverty rate is higher today than in 1979:

This increase is almost exclusively a Hispanic phenomenon. According to Census Bureau statistics, the poverty rate for black children is 4.5 percentage points lower today than in 1979, while the rate for white non-Hispanic children is one-half percentage point higher. But the rate for Hispanic children has increased from 28 percent in poverty to 34.4 percent, and the number of Hispanic children in the United States population has more than doubled.

The writer is a professor at the Baruch College School of Public Affairs, CUNY.
